title: Before 1 July 2017, will Russia allow Turkish citizens to travel to Russia without a visa?
preds: Remote enough to round down (that is, if clarification is wrong-- looks like it is?)

Going with no based on stringent resolve criteria for question.  Exemptions on certain classes of travellers still resolves as 'no' I think. 
Quote in comments by rene and wildwood seem to suggest some visas, sometime in the future but not all

Among the mysteries of this Q is whether it means travel must actually occur, or only that an announcement must be made that it can.  Doesn't matter to me, I hope--I think neither will occur with sufficient clarity before the deadline.  Stay tuned.

"So what did Turkey gain at the Sochi summit? Turkish Economy Minister Nihat Zeybekci told NTV that Russia had lifted the restrictions on work permits in contracting, tourism and timber sectors and hiring of Turkish workers. But another major issue still hiding among the tomatoes is non-resumption of visa-free travel between the two countries. So far, only businesspeople can travel without visas."
Dropping to zero, if it was going to happen anytime soon I think it would have by now.

Unstable fraudulent elections and the added terrorist threat of allowing Turks to freely travel to Russia has led to an impasse between the countries.  President Erdogan appears to be a volatile leader and appeasing him by loosening visa policy would be of very little benefit to the current geopolitical strategy of Russia.  Historically, Russia is very good at protecting their homeland against terrorism, especially since an alliance with Chechnya has been solidified.  The conflict in Raqqa is a major determining factor in negotiating visa free travel from Turkey to Russia, as well.  The Turkish leadership is publicly outraged with the US arming the Kurds for the battle in Raqqa and Russia has taken a laissez faire attitude toward the strategy.  Currently, the Turks are overestimating their geopolitical value and Russia will not give concessions to a country which is overestimating its position in the world.  I predict Russia will not allow Turkish citizens to travel commercially to Russia without a visa.

Russia is preparing to ease visa procedures for Turkish citizens, Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Alexei Meshkov said on Saturday.
The deputy foreign minister reportedly told Sputnik that Russia is ready to facilitate easier visa formalities for businesspeople working with Russia, while he noted that it is also important to work in this regard for Turkish truck drivers.
Regarding visa procedures for airline staff, Meshkov said that they are currently in the final stage of discussions regarding visa procedures for airline staff.
Russia had imposed economic sanctions, including the suspension of visa-free travel, on Turkey at the start of last year.
Last week, the Russian government signed a decree allowing visa-free travel to the country's far eastern Vladivostok city for 18 countries, including Turkey.
https://www.dailysabah.com/diplomacy/2017/04/22/russia-ready-to-ease-visa-procedures-for-turkish-citizens-deputy-fm-meshkov

My guess is that if Russia was going to allow visa free travel before 1 July it would probably have done so at the meeting between Putin and Erdogan in Sochi a few days ago. The Russian Deputy PM said that Putin had said that Russia would continue to require visa for Turkish citizens but that could change depending on the level of cooperation between security forces.  So effectively the new relationship is on trial. A trial of just seven weeks (to 1 July) would seem very short.
Russia will do this for the positive press, after a finite period of time has passed of sufficient length to deter Turkey from ever crossing them again.

The news (see @Rene below) from Reuters sees to indicate that the visa requirement will last. I understand that Russian farmers are doing well from the ban on imported foods. Maybe Putin thinks its better to keep the farms solvent than give consumers cheaper food. A few gain a lot vs the many who pay a bit more. Maybe the time it will take to remove the ban is until the end of the 2017 tomato harvest.

'The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Russia announced its readiness to ease the visa regime for Turkey
The Russian Foreign Ministry said that Moscow is ready to ease the visa regime for some categories of Turkish citizens, particularly large businessmen and holders of service passports. This was stated by Deputy Foreign Minister Alexei Meshkov.
"We have once again confirmed the readiness of the Russian side to follow the path of facilitating visa formalities for holders of business passports, for big business, first of all, for the business that works specifically with Russia," the diplomat told Interfax.
At the same time he considers it an important issue to facilitate visa formalities for truck drivers. Meanwhile, Russian-Turkish consultations on easing the visa regime for the crews of civil aviation vessels, according to Meshkov, are "already in the final stages".'

1. President Putin will allow visa-free travel for diplomats, businessmen, and some categories of workers to further renewing economic ties with Turkey. 
2. He will not open visa-free travel to Turkish citizens at large for security reasons. To do so would make it easier for anti-Russia elements to cross and make Russia more vulnerable to attacks.

Parliamentary ties were suspended following downing of Russian jet
ANKARA
The Turkish parliament is to renew parliamentary ties with the Russian Duma following the resumption of good relations between Ankara and Moscow, a parliamentary official said Friday.
The Grand National Assembly had suspended the friendship group relationship with Russian lawmakers during the political fallout following the downing of a Russian jet by the Turkish Air Force over the Turkey-Syria border in November last year.
After presidents Recep Tayyip Erdogan and Vladimir Putin resolved the dispute in June, the assembly will reconnect with Duma members over the coming days, the official said on condition of anonymity due to restrictions on talking to the media.
Friendship groups develop relationships and cooperation between Turkish lawmakers and their overseas counterparts. There are currently more than 100 such groups. Turkey is also planning to develop links to the parliament in Chad (para. 1-4).

The U.S. Department of State continues to warn U.S. citizens of increased threats from terrorist groups throughout Turkey.  U.S. citizens should avoid travel to southeast Turkey and carefully consider the risks of travel to and throughout the country.  The U.S. Department of State is updating this Travel Warning to reflect the October 29, 2016, decision to order the departure of family members of employees posted to the U.S. Consulate General in Istanbul, Turkey.  The Department of State made this decision based on security information indicating extremist groups are continuing aggressive efforts to attack U.S. citizens in areas of Istanbul where they reside or frequent.  The Consulate General remains open and fully staffed.

Per Dsarin nudge: I misread the question summary. I thought, for 1 out of 5 years, the visa privileges have not been restored, and given limited personal time to do further research, go with that estimate. Instead, assuming it's an appropriate way to estimate, I should consider that for 4 out of 5 years there were privileges, which changes my answer to .8 and 46% respectively.
